data.text:
Scratching on celluloid film is also referred to “direct animation” which is made by etching designs directly onto the film print. These drawings can be made on black liter film or found footage films. What is required to make these films are using permanent markers, paints, and even ink! But here are the essentials you will need to make some cool moving scratch images!

The Essentials :

Light table

16mm Rewind

16mm black liter

16mm splicer and splicing tape

16mm film projector with a take up reel

16mm film core

Dental tool or other type of scratching tool

Hole puncher

Wet paper towel or cloth

Q tips

Clothing line to dry film

STEP 1 : If you are making an found footage film it’s optional but try to watch the footage all the way through if an audio soundtrack applies on the film if not feel free to sift through the film on the 16mm rewind. From there you can figure out which scenes you want to pull from the film. If you are using black or clear liter none of this applies to you.

STEP 2 : Once you’ve found the scenes of your liking or have your black/clear film liter ready cut the strips to about three feet (1 meter long), and tape the strips to the light table keeping it nice and secure while scratching.

STEP 3 : Take the scratch tool and start scratching a design or pattern on the emulsion side of the film strip.

Key Points

Like stop-motion animation slightly alter each frame with subtle scratch marks evolving in each frame keep in mind 24 frames adds up to 1 second of run time.

Make sure your mark fits in the frame so try to scratch very tiny but if you want to fill an entire frame with a solid color block it out with etching out the entire frame and filling it in with marker or paint.

Feel free to even use bleach on footage making the film appear clear and wiping out the image slightly.

make sure to layer your ink or marker because one layer is not enough and your color will look lighter appearing more like a crayon scribble instead of an solid color.

Final Steps

Make sure to hang up your film to air dry after applying multiple layers of ink and marker on it. Make sure the strips not touching one another you wouldn’t want to blend colors from other parts of the film

Splice together the completed pieces of film in the order of your liking make sure when you splice the film together that when it is to be projected that your image isn’t flipped upside down and not playing backwards. And if a sprocket hole is broken chop it then make a splice. Also keep in mind when splicing that the tape doesn’t clog the sprocket holes.

Once everything is ready and set go wind the film up on an take up reel and project it on an 16mm projector.

Have fun scratching!
